custom_fields.name: TS-Status
custom_fields.description: Use this field in ticketing boards to automate the task through various stages of interaction. Critical for most ticketing based rules.

custom_fields.name: TIE Request Type
custom_fields.description: Pick the main category that best captures the overall nature of this ticket. This selection drives which follow-up questions appear in the form, determines routing rules, and sets the appropriate service-level targets.

custom_fields.name: TIE Request Detail
custom_fields.description: Choose the more granular sub-category that pinpoints the specific issue or request. This helps downstream automations—like priority setting, assignment, and reporting—accurately reflect the ticket’s real-world needs.

custom_fields.name: ESCAPE
custom_fields.description: E – Experience-First: Ensure every decision enhances usability and builds contractor trust. S – Simplify: Ruthlessly remove complexity by confirming only features that reduce friction. C – Centralize: Align on how updates unify compliance data under one secure system. A – Automate & Anticipate: Prioritize tools that handle repetitive tasks and prevent issues before they occur. P – Personalize: Confirm client-specific needs are being met with flexibility and clarity. E – Ecosystem: Evaluate requests for integration and partnership potential.

custom_fields.name: Lift
custom_fields.description: Estimate the complexity of this task from “Micro” (a quick few minutes) up to “Project” (multi-week/month effort). This value drives automated due-date calculation and capacity planning—choose the level that best matches the work from triage through delivery.

custom_fields.name: Scope of Work
custom_fields.description: Selected by the team owning the ticket after intake.

custom_fields.name: Who is Affected?
custom_fields.description: This is a generally quantifiable field that simply reports which group of people is most affected. This will have an impact on he prioritization.

custom_fields.name: Number Impacted
custom_fields.description: This field is where the user selects the approximate number of people who are impacted by the issue being reported.

custom_fields.name: Personal Priority
custom_fields.description: Personal Priority is a measurement of how important this task is to the person who is submitting the task.

custom_fields.name: Date Accuracy
custom_fields.description: This field lets the receiving team clarify scheduling confidence even if Lift and Due Date are automated.

data.name: [TIE-1044] Complete Local DC Migration to AWS
data.notes:
Action Plan: Migrating from Local DC to AWS Virtual DC 
 

Phase 1: Planning and Preparation

 
    Requirements Gathering & Analysis
        Define current Active Directory (AD) infrastructure (DC roles, DNS settings, DHCP settings).
        Document dependencies and integrations (e.g., file shares, GPOs, external authentication systems).
    Infrastructure Setup in AWS
        Select AWS Region considering latency and compliance.
        Establish VPC, Subnets, Route Tables, Security Groups, and Network ACLs.
        Ensure VPN or AWS Direct Connect is in place for secure connectivity between on-premise and AWS.
    Network and Security Validation
        Confirm firewall rules, routing rules, VPN tunnels, and ensure AD ports are open (LDAP 389, LDAPS 636, DNS 53, Kerberos 88, SMB 445).
        Implement AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies according to least-privilege principles.

Phase 2: AWS Virtual DC Deployment

 
    Virtual Server Provisioning
        Launch EC2 Instances using Windows Server AMI (e.g., Windows Server 2022).
        Attach storage volumes for SYSVOL and AD Database (ensure performance optimization, using SSD).
        Allocate Elastic IP addresses if required.
    Domain Controller Promotion
        Join the AWS-based Windows Server to the existing domain.
        Promote the new instance to Domain Controller.
        Ensure DNS roles and FSMO roles (Flexible Single Master Operations) replication.

Phase 3: Verification and Synchronization

 
    AD Replication and Health Checks
        Confirm synchronization of AD Database and SYSVOL.
        Verify replication using repadmin, dcdiag, and AD Replication Status Tool.
    DNS Verification
        Confirm internal and external DNS resolution from AWS DC.
        Validate forward and reverse lookup zones.
    Backup and Recovery Setup
        Configure snapshot and backup strategy using AWS Backup or third-party tools.
        Verify recovery process through test restorations.

Phase 4: Activation and Transition

 
    Update DHCP and DNS Configuration
        Update DHCP scope options to point DNS clients to new AWS-based DC.
        Modify DNS settings for servers and clients accordingly.
    FSMO Roles Transfer
        Transfer FSMO roles to the new AWS-based DC.
        Validate the FSMO roles transfer with netdom query fsmo.
    Decommission On-Premise DC (after verification period)
        Demote and remove roles from old DC.
        Decommission physical infrastructure.

Phase 5: Post-Migration Validation

 
    Comprehensive Testing
        User authentication and Group Policy application.
        Application and service accessibility.
        Performance monitoring and tuning as needed.
    Monitoring and Alerting Setup
        Enable AWS CloudWatch alarms and metrics.
        Configure AD-specific monitoring solutions for proactive management.

Phase 6: Continuous Improvement and Maintenance

 
    Regular Maintenance Tasks
        Ensure patching schedules and Windows Server updates.
        Regularly test backups and restore capabilities.
    Periodic Reviews
        Conduct quarterly infrastructure reviews and performance tuning.
        Adapt infrastructure to evolving business and security requirements.

custom_fields.description: Estimate the complexity of this task from “Micro” (a quick few minutes) up to “Project” (multi-week/month effort). This value drives automated due-date calculation and capacity planning—choose the level that best matches the work from triage through delivery.

custom_fields.name: Scope of Work
custom_fields.description: Selected by the team owning the ticket after intake.

custom_fields.name: TS-Status
custom_fields.description: Use this field in ticketing boards to automate the task through various stages of interaction. Critical for most ticketing based rules.

custom_fields.name: TIE Request Type
custom_fields.description: Pick the main category that best captures the overall nature of this ticket. This selection drives which follow-up questions appear in the form, determines routing rules, and sets the appropriate service-level targets.

custom_fields.name: TIE Request Detail
custom_fields.description: Choose the more granular sub-category that pinpoints the specific issue or request. This helps downstream automations—like priority setting, assignment, and reporting—accurately reflect the ticket’s real-world needs.

custom_fields.name: ESCAPE
custom_fields.description: E – Experience-First: Ensure every decision enhances usability and builds contractor trust. S – Simplify: Ruthlessly remove complexity by confirming only features that reduce friction. C – Centralize: Align on how updates unify compliance data under one secure system. A – Automate & Anticipate: Prioritize tools that handle repetitive tasks and prevent issues before they occur. P – Personalize: Confirm client-specific needs are being met with flexibility and clarity. E – Ecosystem: Evaluate requests for integration and partnership potential.

custom_fields.name: Who is Affected?
custom_fields.description: This is a generally quantifiable field that simply reports which group of people is most affected. This will have an impact on he prioritization.

custom_fields.name: Number Impacted
custom_fields.description: This field is where the user selects the approximate number of people who are impacted by the issue being reported.

custom_fields.name: Personal Priority
custom_fields.description: Personal Priority is a measurement of how important this task is to the person who is submitting the task.

custom_fields.name: Estimated time
custom_fields.description: Asana-created. Estimate time to complete a task.

custom_fields.name: Date Accuracy
custom_fields.description: This field lets the receiving team clarify scheduling confidence even if Lift and Due Date are automated.

custom_fields.name: Task Title
custom_fields.description: The quintessential "What Should We Call This" field. Separated out for the purpose of consistent naming automation.

custom_fields.name: Cross Functional Work
custom_fields.description: Select which departments need to coordinate their activity on this task.

custom_fields.name: Approved
custom_fields.description: Has this request been approved by your manager?

custom_fields.name: TS Ticket Type
custom_fields.description: For Salesforce, Cloud and Web tickets, this field is used to assign ownership and determine questions in the ticketing form.

custom_fields.name: ESCAPE MULTI
custom_fields.description: E – Experience-First: Ensure every decision enhances usability and builds contractor trust. S – Simplify: Ruthlessly remove complexity by confirming only features that reduce friction. C – Centralize: Align on how updates unify compliance data under one secure system. A – Automate & Anticipate: Prioritize tools that handle repetitive tasks and prevent issues before they occur. P – Personalize: Confirm client-specific needs are being met with flexibility and clarity. E – Ecosystem: Evaluate requests for integration and partnership potential.

custom_fields.name: Virtual Assistant
custom_fields.description: Used to trigger series of Virtual Assistant upon completion.

custom_fields.name: Work Type
custom_fields.description: This is a field that captures the big rocks of work type. Use for development guidance or work prioritization and categorization.

custom_fields.name: Risk MS
custom_fields.description: This is the multi-select version of Risk vectors related to software development

custom_fields.name: Impact Vector
custom_fields.description: This ticket MOST impacts this vector.
